results.title: Nanook of the North [Silent]
results.creator_credit: Pathe Exchange, Films Incorporated and Robert Joseph Flaherty
results.brief_description: Robert Flaherty was commissioned by the Revillon Fur Company to make an advertising film, and the result of his visit to the Hudson Bay territory of Canada was “Nanook of the North”. It is difficult to realise that Flaherty had to work entirely alone and without the advantages of panchromatic stock. His use of realist material to present not a story but rather a dramatic theme of man’s struggle with his environment opened up a new realm of film-making. It was the first documentary film in the modern sense. The film shows Nanook, the Eskimo hunter, preparing with his family for the summer, his meeting with the white trader, catching walruses, seals and foxes, building an igloo, training his children in the arts of hunting, breaking camp, and finally returning through a wild storm to safety and rest in an old igloo.

results.title: Nano-cadabra
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: Baldino takes the theory of ‘Nano-technology’ as her jumping-off point to explore the connections between science, magic and wonder. Nano-Cadabra is composed of forty abstract narratives, each lasting five seconds or less. In these mini-events, an array of ambiguous objects interact, eerily suggesting movement on the molecular level. Nano-Cadabra also exists as a four-channel installation.

results.title: Nanneella Primary School
results.brief_description: This small rural Primary School of 26 students is at the heart of Nanneella and its residents. With a motto of ‘A School and Community Together’ the Primary School is an integral part of all town events and social gatherings. The students are engaging and fun young individuals with clear ideas and hopes for the future. This film also features a performance from ‘Power Wars’, a musical piece that incorporates science and drama and won Nanneella Primary School the 2009 Archimedes Award.

results.title: Nangiloc-Colignan Community Tackles Salinity
results.creator_credit: Sunraysia Horticultural Centre and Dept of Ag and Rural Affairs
results.brief_description: The Nangiloc - Colignan communtiy are working together to tackle the problem of increased salinity in the soil in the Sunraysia district. Farming and irrigation go hand in hand, and with community effort, the aim is to make sure that farming practices enrich rather tahn deplete a vital resource.

results.title: Nancy goes to Rio
results.creator_credit: Joe Pasternak, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Robert Z Leonard
results.brief_description: Talented actress and dancer Nancy Barklay is vying for a lead role in this Broadway musical set in Brazil. Unfortunately her mother is competing for the same part. The situation becomes intolerable when Nancy follows her mother to Rio in order to wrest the part off her; complications ensue when both women fall for the same man. A featherweight musical filmed in Technicolor, ‘Nancy Goes to Rio’ is mostly remembered for being Carmen Miranda’s second to last picture. The film is essentially a remake of ‘It’s A Date’, Universal, 1940. Songs include ‘Ca-Room Pa-Pa’, ‘Love Is Like This’, ‘Yipsee I-O’, ‘Time And Time Again’, ‘Nancy Goes To Rio’, ‘Shine On’, ‘Harvest Moon’, ‘Magic Is The Moonlight’, ‘Musetta’s Waltz’ and ‘Embraceable You’. Cast includes Ann Sothern, Jane Powell, Barry Sullivan, Carmen Miranda, Louis Calhern.

results.title: Nana
results.brief_description: Handsomely staged adaption of Emile Zola’s celebrated novel about a Parisian coquette who becomes a music hall star. Fame and fortune bring her little happiness however, as two brothers both vie for her affections, leading to a bitter rivalry that ends in tragedy. Director Dorothy Arzner’s only film for Goldwyn also marks the debut of Russian-born actress Anna Sten in Hollywood. Cast also includes Lionel Atwill and Richard Bennett.

results.title: Naming the federal capital of Australia: the ceremony
results.brief_description: Newsreel footage of the ceremonies surrounding the naming of Canberra on 12 March 1913 including scenes of Capital Hill, Andrew Fisher, Billy Hughes, the Light Horse Brigade and the laying of the various foundation stones. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Namibia: a trust betrayed
results.creator_credit: Ramakantha Sarma and United Nations Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “International Zone”.
Traces the tragic history of the Namibian people from before World War I to the present. Once a German colony, later a mandated territory under the League of Nations, Namibia (South West Africa as it was then called) instead of progressing towards independence has been swallowed up into South Africa in defiance of the United Nations and the International Court of Justice. The South African race system has been applied in the territory, where ninety per cent of the population is black.

results.title: Names of sin
results.creator_credit: Karl Holtsnider, Franciscan Communications Centre, Teleketics and Rolf Forsberg
results.brief_description: A dramatization about a nine-year-old girl Missy who is persuaded by her peers to throw a stone at an old lady. She later discovers that the old lady is dying and a personal awareness of having done an unloving act weighs heavily upon her. Her mother’s loving response to her torment and instinctive gestures of consolation even as she lets Missy know the seriousness of her action, frees Missy and she finds her own special way to express her sorrow. The dramatic tension traces the dynamics of the sacrament of Penance, as Missy experiences sorrow, guilt and the peace that comes with forgiveness.
